metadata.title: Development of ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene-functionalized carbon nano-onions composites for biomedical applications

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Diamond & Related Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/diamond
Development of ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene-functionalized carbon nano-onions composites for biomedical applications
Narsimha Mamidia,⁎, Marcelo Renato Martínez Gameroa, Javier Villela Castrejónb, Alex Elías Zúnígaa
a Tecnológico de Monterrey, Monterrey Campus, School of Engineering and Science, Eugenio Garza Sada 2501 Sur, Col. Tecnológico, C.P. 64849 Monterrey, Nuevo León, Mexico b Tecnológico de Monterrey, Centro de Biotecnología-FEMSA, School of Engineering and Science, Av. Eugenio Garza Sada 2501, Monterrey, N.L. C.P. 64849, Mexico
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Carbon nano-onions Ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene Nanocomposites Osteoblasts Strengthening Cytotoxicity
A B S T R A C T
Herein, carbon nano-onions (CNOs) were covalently functionalized with mercaptophenyl methacrylate (MPMA) and ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene/functionalized carbon nano-onions (UHMWPE/f-CNOs) nanocomposites were prepared for the first time. UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites were fabricated by solution mixing followed by hydraulic pressing. The surface chemical structure of f-CNOs, morphology, microstructural properties, thermal stability, and decomposition, crystallinity, mechanical and cytotoxicity of the nanocomposites were evaluated. Biocompatibility assessments of these nanocomposites were studied with the human osteoblast cells. In vitro results displayed excellent cell growth and viability on the surface of nanocomposites over 14 days of incubation without significant cytotoxicity. The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs to osteoblast was depended on its concentration. Increasing the concentration of f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) in UHMWPE improved the biocompatibility of the nanocomposite surface to bone cells. In addition, at a high concentration of f-CNOs (0.1 wt%), the nanocomposite showed the highest improvement in tensile strength 83% as compared to neat UHMWPE. Increasing fCNOs content also leads to enhancement in yield strength, elastic modulus, fracture toughness, and tensile strength. The strengthening of UHMWPE/f-CNOs systems was significantly influenced by the concentration of fCNOs, which revealed its extent of polymer wrapping and degree of dispersion. The elastic deformation process was influenced by the fraction of f-CNOs oriented along with the tensile axis, whereas the deformation performance in the plastic regime was controlled by the wrapping of polymer and polymer-f-CNOs interfacial strength. Nevertheless, these nontoxic UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites would pave the way for the manufacture of artificial implants for potential arthroplasty and other biomedical applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the discovery of C60 fullerenes in 1985, several carbon nanomaterials (CNMs) including carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, carbon nano-horns (CNHs) and carob nano-onions (CNOs) have been subjective of intensive research of nanotechnology and biomedical fields [1–3]. Among them, CNOs are the new class of emerging carbon material that displayed great potential in many applications. CNOs are also known as multi-shell fullerenes, hyperfullerenes, onion-like fullerenes, onion-like carbon and nested fullerenes [4]. CNOs can be polyhedral or spherical in shape and their diameter can be varied from 2 nm to 100 nm based on their synthesis process [4]. The inimitable physicochemical properties of CNOs make them promising nanomaterials for the numerous applications including catalysis, cell imaging,
diagnostic, therapeutic and biomedical applications [5–10]. In general, poor solubility of unfunctionalized CNOs in aqueous solvents, agglomeration, and toxicity have been the main concern for their potential use in biomedical and tissue engineering applications [11]. This issue can be addressed by chemical functionalization on the CNOs surface through covalent or noncovalent methods [12–14]. Indeed, their synthesis, surface chemistry, applications have been investigated systematically [15]. The covalent functionalization of CNOs with different functional groups enhanced their dispersibility and biocompatibility. In addition, their high surface area and small size allow for the functionalization of different biological and therapeutic agents that displayed a wide range of biological applications [16]. These well-established chemistries on CNOs surface allow a researcher to develop specific carbon derivatives soluble in aqueous and organic solvents as
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.diamond.2019.05.020 Received 22 March 2019; Received in revised form 3 May 2019; Accepted 25 May 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: nmamidi@tec.mx (N. Mamidi).
Diamond & Related Materials 97 (2019) 107435
Available online 27 May 2019 0925-9635/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
well as biocompatible [16]. For instance, CNOs were covalently functionalized with folic acid and fluorescein to explore both imaging as well as targeting cancer cells [7]. Recently, CNOs surface structures were modified with heteroatoms using the posttreatment method and improved capacitive and enzyme electrocatalytic properties were observed [17]. Tris(tetramethylcyclopentadienyl) samarium (III) single crystals were directly encapsulated into CNOs by pyrolysis and sublimation [18]. Despite this recent progress, the surface functionalization of CNOs is still needed for their potential use in biomedical applications.
Ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) is a clinical grade biopolymer widely used in biomedical applications [19]. The UHMWPE prevents metal-metal abrasion between the metallic shell and the femoral head of implants. UHMWPE also used in knee and other orthopedic implantations. However, it is still considered as weak material as it's Young's modulus is generally low. Thus, its inherent low strength limits certain biomedical applications. In addition, it causes wear and premature replacement of implants [19]. Moreover, wear debris of UHMWPE causes osteolysis [20]. Therefore, it is important to improve the mechanical properties of UHMWPE, which can be addressed by using appropriate second phase reinforcement. For this, UHMWPE was reinforced with hydroxyapatite (HA) and osteoinductive capabilities were improved. However, it reduced yield strength, strain, and toughness. Moreover, it showed a negative effect on wear resistance [21,22]. Therefore, UHMWPE was reinforced with graphene nanoplatelet and improved wear resistance and mechanical properties were observed [23,24]. Carbon black, MWCNTs and micro and nanoparticle UHMWPE were reported with improved tensile and electrical properties without being used for biomedical applications [24–26]. Carbon nanotubes/graphene nanoparticles/UHMWPE composites were used to investigate piezoresistive, mechanical and cytotoxicity properties [27,28]. However, agglomeration was observed at the higher concentration of CNTs. Furthermore, the mechanical properties were not greatly improved and the detailed biocompatibility was not studied.
Herein, functionalized carbon nano onions (f-CNOs) were evaluated as a potential reinforcement for UHMWPE. For this, a surface functionalization of CNOs with mercaptophenyl methacrylate (MPMA) followed by free radical polymerization was accomplished. Mercaptophenyl methacrylate (MPMA) moiety is a monomer of radiation-sensitive polymer resists and has been used in lithography applications [29]. To study physicochemical and cytotoxicity assessments as well as to explore the potential use of functionalized f-CNOs in orthopedic applications, ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene/functionalized CNOs (UHMWPE/f-CNOs) nanocomposites were prepared by reinforcing with long chain UHMWPE. Two types of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites with 0.01 and 0.1 wt% of f-CNOs were fabricated by ultra-sonication followed by hydraulic pressing. These nanocomposites were investigated by DSC, TGA, tensile, and SEM analysis. The presence of f-CNOs enhanced the roughness of nanocomposites as identified by SEM. Mechanical, thermal and cytotoxicity properties of nanocomposites were significantly improved than pristine UHMWPE. The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs was measured with osteoblast cells with a varying concentration of nanocomposites over 14 days of incubation. The results reveal that the cell growth and viability were significantly improved with increasing the weight percentage of f-CNOs suggesting a nontoxic influence or positive effect of f-CNOs on bone cells.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and methods
sections.text:
All the chemicals and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. 4-Mercaptophenol, methacryloyl chloride, 2,2′-azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN), Nhydroxysuccinimide (NHS), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP), 1-ethyl3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC), and UHMWPE were
purchased from Sigma Aldrich, USA. Osteoblast cells were purchased from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC, Manassas, VA). Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F12 without phenol red (DMEM/ F12), phosphate buffered saline (PBS) pH 7.4, fetal bovine serum (FBS), penicillin/streptomycin and trypsin were bought from Gibco Invitrogen (CA, U.S.A.). CellTiter96®AQueous One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay was obtained from Promega, (WI, U.S.A.). LIVE/DEAD Cell Imaging Kit was purchased from Molecular Probes, Life Technologies Corp. (CA, U.S.A.). G418 disulfate salt, Alizarin Red S, dexamethasone, ascorbic acid, β-glycerophosphate, and cetylpyridinium chloride were purchased from Sigma Aldrich (MO, U.S.A.).

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis
sections.text: The pristine CNOs were a generous gift from Dr. Emmanuel Segura Cárdenas (Tecnológico de Monterrey, Monterrey Campus, Nuevo León, México). Carboxylic acid functional group on CNO was generated by a previously reported method [12]. Whereas CNOs-mercaptophenol (CNOs-MP), CNOs-MPMA and CNOs-PMPMA (f-CNOs) were prepared as shown below.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Synthesis of CNOs-MP
sections.text:
The synthesis was accomplished according to a modified reported reaction protocol and the products obtained in good yields [30]. Pure carbon nano-onions CNOs (100mg) were dispersed in anhydrous DMF (100mL) using an ultrasonic bath for 60min. N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS, 350mg) and 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP, 350mg) were added to dispersion solution and the reaction mixture was further sonicated for 30min. Then, 570mg of 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC) was added to the reaction mixture and sonicated for 90min. After that 4-mercaptophenol (MP) was added, sonicated for 60min and the resulted reaction mixture was stirred at 60 °C under N2 for 2 days. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the supernatant was removed by centrifugation. The resulted solid was washed with DMF, methanol, DMF/triethylamine (9.9: 01) and ethyl acetate. Finally, a black solid was obtained (CNOsMP) after desiccation under vacuum.
1H NMR (500MHz, DMSO‑d6): δH= 8.14 (2H, d, J=8.3 Hz, m,m′ArH), 7.55 (2H, d, J=8.3 Hz, o,o′-ArH), 6.31 (1H, s, C]CH), 5.94 (1H, s, C]CH), 2.00 (3H, s, CH3).

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Synthesis of CNOs-PMPMA
sections.text:
CNOs-MP (50mg) was dispersed in anhydrous THF (50mL) by sonicator bath for 30min. Diisopropylethylamine (1.0 mL) was added and the mixture was further sonicated for 60min. Then, methacryloyl chloride (MA) (1.0 mL) was added to the reaction mixture at 0 °C and sonicated for 30min. Then, the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature under N2 for 1 day. After that, the supernatant was removed by centrifugation. The resulted solid was washed with THF, dichloromethane, and HCl (0.01M aqueous). The residue was vacuum dried to produce monomer CNOs-MPMA as a black solid. Then, 50mg of CNOs-MPMA and azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 1 wt%) were dissolved in anhydrous THF (20mL) and sonicated for 60min. Then, the reaction mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 2 days. Afterward, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the supernatant was removed by centrifugation.
The resulted solid was washed with diethyl ether and dichloromethane. Finally, the black solid was vacuum dried and stored in a desiccator for further use. The functionalized CNOs-PMPMA (f-CNOs) was characterized using Raman, TGA, 1H NMR and GPC analysis. 1H NMR (500MHz, DMSO‑d6): δH 8.12 (2H, br s, m,m′-ArH), 7.47 (2H, br s, o,o′-ArH), 2.05 (2H, br peak, CH2 polymeric), 1.39–1.09 (3H, br peak, CH3 polymeric).

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Fabrication of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites
sections.text:
UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites were prepared with two
different concentrations of f-CNOs (0.01 wt% and 0.1 wt%) using a previously reported method [28]. Briefly, f-CNOs were ultra-sonicated for 30min in ethanol for the uniform dispersion. Then, UHMWPE (45 g) was added and ultra-sonicated for 30min to obtain a homogeneous dispersion. Next, ethanol was removed using vacuum filtration and dried in a hot oven at 80 °C until it was completely dried. The compositions selected for this study were UHMWPE, UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) and UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%), respectively. Considering the high surface area of CNOs, the weight content of the reinforcement phase (f-CNOs) was kept very low in the current study. The obtain homogeneous UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposite powder was loaded on 2mm of stainless steel molds and placed in CARVER 4122 hydraulic heating press at 150 °C followed by 24MPa pressure for 15min. After that, the pressure was released and molds were cooled to room temperature to obtain 2mm of UHMWPE/f-CNOs sheets.

sections.heading: 2.3. Biocompatibility evaluation for UHMWPE and UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites
sections.text: Human osteoblasts, the bone-forming cells were used to evaluate in vitro biocompatibility of the samples. The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs measured by culturing osteoblasts in medium with two different concentrations of f-CNOs (0.01 and 0.1 wt%) and measuring cell viability and morphology.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Morphological evaluations of osteoblasts on composites
sections.text: Prior to cell seeding on 24 well plates, pure UHMWPE and f-CNOs nanocomposites were cut into a disk shape with ~15.5mm of diameter and decorated on 24 well plates. Then, osteoblast cells were seeded on 24 well plates using a cell density of 1× 104 cells/mL in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F12 (DMEM/F12) supplemented with 2.5 mM of L-glutamine, 0.3mg/mL of G418 disulfate salt, 1% of penicillin/streptomycin and 10% of fetal bovine serum. The cells were incubated for 24 h in a humidified atmosphere at 5% CO2. Then, the medium was transferred from the well plats and rinsed several times with phosphate buffer solution. After 14 days of incubation, cell images were recorded by an optical microscope (Model IN200A-5M, Amscope, Chino, CA).

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Osteoblast viability on f-CNOs nanocomposite substrates
sections.text: Cell viability was measured by CellTiter96®AQueous One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay, for this: pure UHMWPE and f-CNOs nanocomposites were cut into a disk shape with ~6.3 mm of diameter and decorated on 96 well plates. Then, the cells were seeded on the surface of the samples at a density of 1×104 cells per well (~3.12× 104 cells/ cm−2). The medium was changed on the next day to remove non-adherent cells, after that the medium was changed every third day. The cell number was evaluated after 1, 3, 7, and 14 days post-seeding using CellTiter96®. In addition, cell viability was determined using the LIVE/ DEAD Cell Imaging Kit and visualized using fluorescence microscopy.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterizations
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS EVO® MA 25, Ostalbkreis, Baden-Württemberg, and Germany) was used to measure the morphological properties of UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites. UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites were frozen in liquid nitrogen for 2 h and then fractured. The cross-sections of the freeze-dried surface were gold coated before to SEM examination. Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, TA Q2000, New Castle, DE) was used to measure crystallinity and melting temperature of the samples at a scan rate of 10 °C/min from 25 to 180 °C under N2 atmosphere. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) was used to study the mass loss of the samples. The heating rate was 10 °C/min under N2 atmosphere at a temperature range from 20 °C to 800 °C. Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw inVia Raman microscope with a green laser of
514 nm) was used to measure vibrational and rotational modes of the samples. The Lorentzian fit was used to calculate D/G ratios of p-CNOs and CNOs-PMPMA samples. JEOL Model JNM ECX (500MHz) NMR spectrometer was used to record 1H NMR in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO‑d6) as a solvent. Gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Agilent Technologies 1260 Infinity Series instrument) analysis was used to measure the molecular weights and polydispersity index (PDI) of CNOs-PMPMA (f-CNOs) with PL gel mixed C and B 10-μm columns. A Tensile-testing machine (Instron 3365, Instron, and Norwood, MA) was used to measure the mechanical properties of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites according to ASTM D 638. The size of the tensile sample was 33.0 mm×6.0mm×2.0mm and the crosshead speed was 50mm/min. Three samples from each composition were tested for measuring tensile strength, elastic modulus, and toughness. Elastic modulus (E) was calculated by measuring the slope of the axial stressstrain curve of each plot. Yield stress (YS) was measured at the point of stress-strain plot and tensile strength (TS) was the highest stress the film could tolerate. Surftest SJ-210 Mitutoyo profilometer (Mitutoyo, Guadalupe, Nuevo Leon, Mexico) was used to measure the roughness (Ra) of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites and pure UHMWPE.

sections.heading: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sections.text: All the quantitative data were expressed as mean ± standard deviations with n=3. Statistical analysis was performed by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey's post hoc tests using Minitab17 (Minitab, State College, PA) and statistical significance was considered at p≤ 0.05.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
A carboxylic acid functional group consisted CNOs-COOH was prepared using earlier reported method [16] and CNOs-COOH was esterified with 4-mercaptophenol in the presence of N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS). Then, the resulted thioester (CNOs-MP) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) and treated with methacryloyl chloride in the presence of N,N-diisopropylethylamine at 0 °C and stirred for 48 h. After the reaction, the supernatant was removed by centrifugation to produce methacrylated CNOs (CNOs-MPMA) as a black solid. The black solid was isolated and washed several times with DMF. Then, the functionalized black solid was polymerized in the presence of 1 wt% of azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) and it provided a black solid CNOs-PMPMA (Scheme 1). The resulted CNOs-PMPMA was characterized using Raman, TGA, 1H NMR, and GPC. Raman curves of pure CNOs and CNOs-PMPMA were recorded and presented in Fig. S1a (see Supporting information). Pure CNOs showed the characteristic D and G bands at 1350 and 1575 cm−1, respectively. Whereas Raman spectrum of CNOs-PMPMA was exhibited somewhat heightening of Dband (1355 cm−1) and G-band (1578 cm−1) than pure CNOs. It revealed that carboxylic groups on the surface of CNOs were converted into thioester. The intensity ratio of the D and G bands helped us to estimate the functionalization of CNOs. The calculated D/G ratios of pCNOs and CNOs-PMPMA are 0.31 and 0.91 respectively. The higher D/ G ratio of CNOs-PMPMA compared to p-CNOs clearly shows the surface functionalization of CNOs. This information is in good agreement with the information obtained from NMR, GPC, and TGA analyses. A similar phenomenon was observed on CNOs subjected to p-aminobenzoic acid and 4-[(trimethylsilyl)ethynyl]aniline amidation reactions [7].
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to measure the thermal stability of CNOs-PMPMA. TGA curves of pure CNOs and CNOs-PMPMA were presented in Fig. S1b (see Supporting information). Weight loss curve of pure CNOs was observed in the temperature range of 725 to 667 °C. However, after covalent functionalization, the decomposition temperature of CNOs-PMPMA was dropped to 620 °C to 560 °C. It indicates that under inert gas, PMPMA moiety bound to CNOs was decomposed at a lower temperature, enabling the selective removal of the
functional groups on the surface of CNOs. TGA results indicate suitable thermal stability of CNOs-PMPMA for biomedical applications. Further, 1H NMR spectra of CNOs-MPMA monomer and CNOs-PMPMA polymer were recorded and presented in Fig. S2 (see Supporting information). The 1H NMR peaks of monomer and polymer were clearly assignable. The olefinic protons of CNOsMPMA monomer appeared at δ 6.3 and 5.9 ppm (Fig. S2a, red circle), however, these protons were disappeared in the 1H NMR spectrum of CNOs-PMPMA polymer (Fig. S2b); it indicates the polymerization reaction of monomer. Predominantly, CNOs-PMPMA showed one broad peak at δ 8.1 ppm for two meta protons of the phenyl ring and another broad peak at δ 7.5 ppm for two ortho protons of the phenyl ring. Polymeric methylene (CH2) group appeared at δ 2.05 ppm and aliphatic methyl (CH3) group of a polymer was unveiled at δ 1.3 ppm. Thus, the 1H NMR analysis was confirmed the complete conversion of monomer into the polymer as well as the chemical structure of functionalized carbon nano-onions (f-CNOs) achieved from the free radical polymerization. In addition, the molecular weight of synthesized CNOsPMPMA was measured using gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and presented in Fig. S3 (Supporting information). The weight-average molecular weight (Mw) was found to be 50,432 along with 1.1 of polydispersity index (PDI).
After the characterization of functionalized CNOs [hereafter CNOsPMPMA was indicated as f-CNOs], UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites were prepared by ultra-sonication followed by hydraulic pressing with two different concentrations of f-CNOs (0.01 wt% and 0.1 wt%). We have selected low weight fractions of 0.01 and 0.1 wt% to ensure uniform dispersion of f-CNOs in the UHMWPE matrix. Initially, homogeneous UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposite powder was prepared by ultra-sonication method then UHMWPE/f-CNOs sheets (2mm thickness) were fabricated by hydraulic pressing. Such developed UHMWPE/ f-CNOs nanocomposite sheets were characterized.
The microstructure of freeze-dried fractured surface areas of pristine UHMWPE and UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites was examined by SEM analysis and results were depicted in Fig. 1. The SEM analysis
clearly revealed that cross-sections of freeze-dried pristine UHMWPE consisted of a smooth surface area (Fig. 1a), whereas cross-sections of freeze-dried UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) exhibited a rough surface without agglomerations (Fig. 1b). Which indicates that f-CNOs were homogeneously dispersed within a matrix of long-chain UHMWPE. At the high concentration (0.1 wt%), f-CNOs were blended within the UHMWPE matrix and the irregular structure was observed (Fig. 1c). The SEM results reveal homogeneous distribution and reinforcement of f-CNOs within a matrix of UHMWPE long chains.
The stress-strain curve of pure UHMWPE and UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites were attained from a universal tensile-testing machine and the results were presented in Fig. 2. The tensile stress of UHMWPE/fCNOs (0.1 wt%), UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) and UHMWPE was calculated to be 83.1MPa, 45.06MPa, and 28.1MPa, respectively. A maximum enhancement in tensile stress up to 83MPa was achieved with 0.1 wt% of f-CNOs, as compared to 28MPa in pure UHMWPE. Similarly, the tensile strength, yield strength, and Young's modulus of UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites were significantly improved than pure UHMWPE. The tensile results revealed that the strengthening mechanism was significantly influenced by the microstructural changes in UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites as a function of f-CNOs concentration. This could be due to the homogeneous dispersion of f-CNOs within the UHMWPE matrix and transfer of external force between the polymer matrix and f-CNOs. This elongation might be due to Van der Waals attractions or π–π interactions between the f-CNOs and UHMWPE long chains. The strengthening mechanism was postulated as follows. Fig. 3b, c showed uneven area on the surface of UHMWPE/fCNOs (0.01 and 0.1 wt%) composites. The absence of similar structural features on the surface of pure UHMWPE (Fig. 3a) confirmed the rough surface was caused by the presence of f-CNOs. The rough area might be originated from the uniform wrapping of polymer chains on the finely distributed carbon nano-onions and embedded within the matrix. The polymer-CNOs interface strength became more critical during the deformation process. Interface strength required to restrict deformation when effective load transferred between reinforcement (f-CNOs) and

polymer matrix. In this system, f-CNOs oriented in the directions other than the tensile axis and shear force became active along these interfaces to restrict the elongation. Thus, the interface between polymer and f-CNOs was strong in UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites due to the better wrapping. As a result, the shear force could transfer successfully from the polymer matrix to reinforcement (f-CNOs). In addition, provides extra strength due to the excellent wrapping of a polymer matrix. As shown in the stress-strain plot (Fig. 2) of UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt %) composites, the strength was gradually increased with strain, thereby signifying the strengthening of UHMWPE. Owing to the excellent wrapping, the f-CNOs in all the directions became effective in UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%), generating higher strength than pure UHMWPE.
MPMA moiety on f-CNOs causes mechanical interlocking along with uniform polymer wrapping leads to enhanced tensile properties. From the fractured area of nanocomposites, it was clear that f-CNOs absorb a significant amount of energy before the final fracture.
Accordingly, composites can sustain more strain and stress without failure than pure UHMWPE. It hypothesized that the f-CNOs on the fractured area are supported and tolerated the stress until fractured. Thus the content of f-CNOs displayed a significant role in the strengthening of UHMWPE, which is one of the primary characteristics of the medical devices.
The melting temperature and crystallinity of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites were measured by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). DSC curves indicated that there was no chemical reaction between f-CNOs and UHMWPE. The DSC results revealed that the crystallinity of pure UHMWPE was progressively improved with reinforcement of f-CNOs. All the samples were exhibited at a melting temperature in a range of 134–136 °C (Fig. 4). Pristine UHMWPE showed 38.02 ± 27 of a degree of crystallinity (DOC), whereas
UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) displayed 44.36 ± 21 of DOC. UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) exhibited 47.16 ± 18 of DOC.
Thermal decomposition and stability behavior of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites were examined by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). The non-isothermal decomposition properties of all the samples were presented in Fig. 5. The thermal decomposition of nanocomposites appeared in the temperature range of 439 to 513 °C. As showed in Fig. 5, UHMWPE was exhibited initial degradation temperature (T0.1) around at 440 °C and midpoint degradation temperature (T0.5) at 509 °C.
UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) was showed T0.1 around at 442 °C and T0.5 at 511 °C. In addition, UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) was displayed T0.1 around at 444 °C and T0.5 at 513 °C. Thus, TGA results reveal that thermal degradation of UHMWPE was significantly decreased in the presence of f-CNOs. This could be due to the restriction of UHMWPE chain motions and reduced the mobility at the interface.
The roughness (Ra) profile of UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites and pristine UHMWPE was presented in Fig. 6 and improved roughness was detected. Specifically, UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) exhibited 0.311mm of roughness whereas UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.01 wt%) showed 0.252mm of roughness. On the other hand, pristine UHMWPE exhibited around 0.121mm of roughness. Accordingly, UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) showed the highest roughness profile; demonstrating that fCNOs were amalgamated with UHMWPE long chains and interrupt the original flat surface area of UHMWPE. This roughness can be triggered the cell adhesion that induces cell growth on the surface of the nanocomposites [28].
It is important to screen the cytotoxicity properties of f-CNOs composites for the potential use in biomedical devices. To investigate the cytotoxic effect of f-CNOs, the cell viability and LIVE/DEAD cell imaging assays were performed with human osteoblasts. The viability results of the samples were compared with tissue culture plate (TC plate as a control) and presented in Fig. 7. At day zero, all the samples were grasped an equal number of cells, however, after day one, 56% of cell adhesion was observed in all the samples, whereas 93% of cell adhesion was observed in the TC plate. Generally, cell viability depends on cell adhesion, cell-cell interaction, and surface-cell recognition. For instance, pristine UHMWPE was showed improved cell number at day 3, day 7 and day 14. On the other hand, UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) nanocomposite was maintained superior viability throughout the experiment (Fig. 7), this could be due to the mechanobiological properties (surface-cell interactions). The results indicate the positive effect of fCNOs on bone cells. This could be due to the improved roughness on the surface of UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) composite. Ultimately, these results reveal that UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) nanocomposites can support to the exceptional cell growth.
The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs was assessed by incubating osteoblasts in culture medium containing nanocomposite disks at different
concentrations of f-CNOs. Fig. 8 displays the optical images of the cells incubated for 14 days. As seen in Fig. 8, a small percentage of DEAD cells were observed and> 97% of LIVE cell confluences were observed in all the treatment (Fig. 8). The morphology observations suggested that all the cells were attached on the surface of composites and the cell growth was progressively improved from 0.01 to 0.1 wt% of f-CNOs content in UHMWPE. The cell growth of composites was far better than TC plate and pristine UHMWPE. It indicates a positive effect of f-CNOs on the survival of bone cells. In addition, UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites were also showed stretched morphology observations. This could be due to the presence of f-CNOs within UHMWPE matrix. f-CNOs could interrupt the homogeneous surface of pure UHMWPE and created a
rough surface that triggered cell growth. Consequently, the surface chemical interactions, a contact angle with cell media and the surface morphology might have played a major role in the enhancement of cell growth. It is hypothesized that f-CNOs were well dispersed within the UHMWPE matrix and wrapped by polymer matrix provided biocompatible UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites.
In light of the discussion on tensile properties and biocompatibility,
UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) shown excellent improvement in mechanical properties as well as biocompatibility as compare to UHMWPE. In this consequence, a composition of f-CNOs would be further optimized by extending above 0.1 wt% to obtained satisfactory enrichment in mechanical properties without sacrificing the biocompatibility.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A versatile chemical strategy was developed for the surface functionalization of CNOs with mercaptophenyl methacrylate moiety. The functionalized f-CNOs have the capability to fabricate UHMWPE/fCNOs nanocomposites with reinforcement of long-chain UHMWPE. The concentration of f-CNOs was found critical for the improvement of biocompatibility and mechanical properties. UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt %) showed maximum progress in tensile strength 83% as compared to pristine UHMWPE. Yield strength, fracture toughness, elastic modulus, and tensile strength were greatly influenced by f-CNOs content. The content and uniform distribution of f-CNOs and matrix-reinforcement interfacial forces were found regulating the strengthening mechanism. The biocompatibility of UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites to osteoblast cells was found dose-dependent and the results showed admirable cell viability after 14 days. LIVE/DEAD results reveal that> 97% of osteoblast cells were survived on the surface of nanocomposites. The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs was also influenced by the roughness of nanocomposites. UHMWPE/f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) the composite showed good biocompatibility. This study suggested that f-CNOs content higher than 0.1 wt% may promote further optimization with significant progress in
mechanical properties and essential biocompatibility for orthopedic applications.
Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors have no conflict of interests.

referenceMentions.context: CNOs are also known as multi-shell fullerenes, hyperfullerenes, onion-like fullerenes, onion-like carbon and nested fullerenes [4].
CNOs can be polyhedral or spherical in shape and their diameter can be varied from 2 nm to 100 nm based on their synthesis process [4].

In general, poor solubility of unfunctionalized CNOs in aqueous solvents, agglomeration, and toxicity have been the main concern for their potential use in biomedical and tissue engineering applications [11].
Indeed, their synthesis, surface chemistry, applications have been investigated systematically [15].
In addition, their high surface area and small size allow for the functionalization of different biological and therapeutic agents that displayed a wide range of biological applications [16].
For instance, CNOs were covalently functionalized with folic acid and fluorescein to explore both imaging as well as targeting cancer cells [7].
Recently, CNOs surface structures were modified with heteroatoms using the posttreatment method and improved capacitive and enzyme electrocatalytic properties were observed [17].
Tris(tetramethylcyclopentadienyl) samarium (III) single crystals were directly encapsulated into CNOs by pyrolysis and sublimation [18].
Ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) is a clinical grade biopolymer widely used in biomedical applications [19].
In addition, it causes wear and premature replacement of implants [19].
Moreover, wear debris of UHMWPE causes osteolysis [20].
Moreover, it showed a negative effect on wear resistance [21,22].
Moreover, it showed a negative effect on wear resistance [21,22].
Therefore, UHMWPE was reinforced with graphene nanoplatelet and improved wear resistance and mechanical properties were observed [23,24].
Therefore, UHMWPE was reinforced with graphene nanoplatelet and improved wear resistance and mechanical properties were observed [23,24].
Carbon nanotubes/graphene nanoparticles/UHMWPE composites were used to investigate piezoresistive, mechanical and cytotoxicity properties [27,28].
Carbon nanotubes/graphene nanoparticles/UHMWPE composites were used to investigate piezoresistive, mechanical and cytotoxicity properties [27,28].
Mercaptophenyl methacrylate (MPMA) moiety is a monomer of radiation-sensitive polymer resists and has been used in lithography applications [29].
Carboxylic acid functional group on CNO was generated by a previously reported method [12].
The synthesis was accomplished according to a modified reported reaction protocol and the products obtained in good yields [30].
1 wt%) using a previously reported method [28].

A carboxylic acid functional group consisted CNOs-COOH was prepared using earlier reported method [16] and CNOs-COOH was esterified with 4-mercaptophenol in the presence of N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS).
A similar phenomenon was observed on CNOs subjected to p-aminobenzoic acid and 4-[(trimethylsilyl)ethynyl]aniline amidation reactions [7].
This roughness can be triggered the cell adhesion that induces cell growth on the surface of the nanocomposites [28].

metadata.abstractText: Herein, carbon nano-onions (CNOs) were covalently functionalized with mercaptophenyl methacrylate (MPMA) and ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene/functionalized carbon nano-onions (UHMWPE/f-CNOs) nanocomposites were prepared for the first time. UHMWPE/f-CNOs composites were fabricated by solution mixing followed by hydraulic pressing. The surface chemical structure of f-CNOs, morphology, microstructural properties, thermal stability, and decomposition, crystallinity, mechanical and cytotoxicity of the nanocomposites were evaluated. Biocompatibility assessments of these nanocomposites were studied with the human osteoblast cells. In vitro results displayed excellent cell growth and viability on the surface of nanocomposites over 14 days of incubation without significant cytotoxicity. The cytotoxicity of f-CNOs to osteoblast was depended on its concentration. Increasing the concentration of f-CNOs (0.1 wt%) in UHMWPE improved the biocompatibility of the nanocomposite surface to bone cells. In addition, at a high concentration of f-CNOs (0.1 wt%), the nanocomposite showed the highest improvement in tensile strength 83% as compared to neat UHMWPE. Increasing fCNOs content also leads to enhancement in yield strength, elastic modulus, fracture toughness, and tensile strength. The strengthening of UHMWPE/f-CNOs systems was significantly influenced by the concentration of fCNOs, which revealed its extent of polymer wrapping and degree of dispersion. The elastic deformation process was influenced by the fraction of f-CNOs oriented along with the tensile axis, whereas the deformation performance in the plastic regime was controlled by the wrapping of polymer and polymer-f-CNOs interfacial strength. Nevertheless, these nontoxic UHMWPE/f-CNOs nanocomposites would pave the way for the manufacture of artificial implants for potential arthroplasty and other biomedical applications.
